title: Patrick O'Byrne (politician)
text:
Patrick Joseph O'Byrne <a href="Sovereign%20Military%20Order%20of%20Malta">KM</a> (August 1870 – 20 January 1944) was an Irish <a href="Irish%20republicanism">republican</a> and <a href="Sinn%20F%C3%A9in">Sinn Féin</a> politician.
Politics.
O'Byrne was elected unopposed as a Sinn Féin <a href="Teachta%20D%C3%A1la">Teachta Dála</a> (TD) to the <a href="Second%20D%C3%A1il">2nd Dáil</a> at the <a href="1921%20Irish%20elections">1921 elections</a> for the <a href="Tipperary%20Mid%2C%20North%20and%20South%20%28D%C3%A1il%20constituency%29">Tipperary Mid, North and South</a> constituency.
He opposed the <a href="Anglo-Irish%20Treaty">Anglo-Irish Treaty</a> and <a href="Anglo-Irish%20Treaty%20D%C3%A1il%20vote">voted against it</a>. He stood as an anti-Treaty Sinn Féin candidate at the <a href="1922%20Irish%20general%20election">1922 general election</a> but was not elected. He did not follow <a href="%C3%89amon%20de%20Valera">Éamon de Valera</a> who split from Sinn Féin in 1926 to found the <a href="Fianna%20F%C3%A1il">Fianna Fáil</a> party to enter the Dáil.
Title and family.
He was the son of was John O'Byrne of Corville, <a href="County%20Tipperary">County Tipperary</a> (who had originally been granted the title of Count by the Pope) and his mother was Eleanor von Hübner, the daughter of Austrian diplomat <a href="Count%20Joseph%20Alexander%20H%C3%BCbner">Count Joseph Alexander Hübner</a>. He was a direct descendant of Edward Byrne (c.1739–1804), a wealthy Dublin merchant and Chairman of the Catholic Convention which campaigned for <a href="Penal%20Laws%20%28Ireland%29">Catholic rights</a>, and his son John Dominick Byrne, who was a member of the <a href="United%20Irishmen">United Irishmen</a>.
Patrick O'Byrne married Bernadette Boland in <a href="Sneem">Sneem</a>, <a href="County%20Kerry">County Kerry</a> in 1897. His brother-in-law was <a href="John%20Boland%20%28Irish%20nationalist%20politician%29">John Pius Boland</a>, the <a href="Irish%20Home%20Rule%20movement">Home Rule</a> <a href="Member%20of%20parliament">MP</a> for <a href="South%20Kerry%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">South Kerry</a>. O'Byrne died in 1944 and is buried in St. Cronan's graveyard, <a href="Roscrea">Roscrea</a>, County Tipperary.
